00001 /*! @mainpage TEMU User Guide
00002  @author Heng Yin <hyin@cs.berkeley.edu>
00003 
00004  @section main_intro TEMU Overview
00005 
00006 TEMU is a whole-system dynamic binary analysis platform that we
00007 developed on the basis of a whole-system emulator,
00008 QEMU. We run an entire system, including the
00009 operating system and applications in this emulator, and observe in a
00010 fine-grained manner how the binary code of interest is executed.
00011 The whole-system approach in TEMU is motivated by several considerations:
00012 
00013 <ul>
00014 <li> Many analyses require fine-grained instrumentation (i.e.,
00015 at instruction level) on binary code. By dynamically translating the
00016 emulated code, the whole-system emulator enables fine-grained
00017 instrumentation.
00018 
00019 <li> Whole-system emulator presents us a whole-system view.  The
00020 whole-system view enables us to analyze the operating system kernel
00021 and interactions between multiple processes. In contrast, many other
00022 binary analysis tools (e.g., Valgrind, DynamoRIO, Pin) only provide a
00023 local view (i.e., a view of a single user-mode process). This is
00024 particularly important for analyzing malicious code, because many
00025 attacks  involve multiple processes, and kernel
00026 attacks such as rootkits have become increasingly popular.
00027 
00028 <li> A whole-system emulator provides an excellent isolation
00029 between the analysis components and the code under analysis. As a
00030 result, it is more difficult for the code under analysis to
00031 interfere with analysis results.
00032 </ul>
00033 
00034 The design of TEMU is motivated by several challenges and considerations:
00035 <ul>
00036 <li>  The whole-system emulator only provides us only the hardware-level view
00037 of the emulated system, whereas we need a software-level view to get
00038 meaningful analysis results. Therefore, we need a mechanism that can
00039 extract the OS-level semantics from the emulated system. For
00040 example, we need to know what process is currently running and what
00041 module an instruction comes from.
00042 
00043 <li> In addition, many analyses require reasoning about how
00044 specific data depends on its data sources and how it propagates throughout
00045 the system. We enable this using whole-system dynamic taint
00046 analysis.
00047 
00048 <li> We need to provide a well-designed programming interface (i.e., API)
00049 for users to implement their own plugins on TEMU to perform their
00050 customized analysis. Such an interface can hide unnecessary details
00051 from users and reuse the common functionalities.
00052 
00053 </ul>
00054 
00055 \image html overview.png
00056 
00057 With these considerations in mind, we have designed the architecture of
00058 TEMU, as shown in the figure above. We build the {\em
00059 semantics extractor} to extract OS-level semantics information from
00060 the emulated system. We build the {\em taint analysis engine} to
00061 perform dynamic taint analysis. We define and implement an interface
00062 (i.e, TEMU API) for users to easily implement their own analysis
00063 modules (i.e. TEMU plugins). These modules can be loaded and
00064 unloaded at runtime to perform designated analyses. We implemented
00065 TEMU in Linux, and at the time of writing, TEMU can be used to
00066 analyze binary code in Windows 2000, Windows XP, and  Linux
00067 systems.
00068 Below we describe these three components
00069 respectively.
00070 
00071 
00072  @section main_overview Overview
00073 
00074  @section main_build How to build TEMU and TEMU plugins
00075 
00076  @section main_api API Reference
00077 */
